fact: Kyoto was Japan's capital for over 1,000 years and is famous for its historic temples and beautiful gardens.
Machu Picchu was built in the 15th century by the Inca Empire and is often called the 'Lost City of the Incas.'
Venice is made up of 118 small islands, separated by canals and connected by bridges.
Central Park in New York City is larger than the country of Monaco.
The Sydney Opera House's iconic design was inspired by the sails of boats in Sydney Harbor.
Reykjavik is the northernmost capital in the world and is known for its stunning views of the Northern Lights.
Cappadocia is famous for its 'fairy chimneys,' which are unique rock formations created by volcanic eruptions.
The Sagrada Familia in Barcelona has been under construction since 1882 and is expected to be completed in 2026.
Cape Town's Table Mountain is over 260 million years old, making it one of the oldest mountains in the world.
The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the tallest building in the world, standing at 828 meters (2,717 feet).
The Eiffel Tower can be up to 15 cm taller in the summer due to the expansion of the metal in the heat.
The blue domes of Santorini's churches are meant to represent the sea and sky.
Rio de Janeiro is home to the world's largest Carnival festival, which attracts over 2 million people each year.
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world, with over 1,500 fountains.
Petra is known as the 'Rose City' due to the pink-colored sandstone cliffs from which it was carved.
Prague's Astronomical Clock is the third-oldest astronomical clock in the world and the oldest one still in operation.
Bali is home to the world's largest turtle conservation center, dedicated to the protection of endangered sea turtles.
Vancouver has one of the mildest climates in Canada and is often ranked as one of the world's most livable cities.
Edinburgh is the world's first UNESCO City of Literature, a title it earned in 2004.
Amsterdam's canals cover more than 100 kilometers and have 1,500 bridges, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the North.'
Jerusalem is considered a holy city by three major religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
Lisbon is older than Rome, making it one of the oldest cities in Western Europe.
The Great Pyramid of Giza, located just outside of Cairo, is the last remaining wonder of the ancient world.
Buenos Aires is known as the 'Paris of South America' due to its European-style architecture and vibrant culture.
Kyiv is home to one of the deepest metro stations in the world, Arsenalna, which is 105.5 meters below ground.
Stockholm is built on 14 islands, connected by more than 50 bridges.
Marrakech's Medina is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, known for its vibrant souks (markets) and stunning palaces.
Athens is one of the oldest cities in the world, with recorded history going back over 3,400 years.
Bangkok's real name is the longest city name in the world, containing 169 characters in Thai.
Berlin has more museums than rainy days in a year, with over 180 museums to explore.
Hanoi is known for its centuries-old architecture and a rich culture with Southeast Asian, Chinese, and French influences.
Bruges is often called the 'Venice of the North' due to its canals and medieval buildings.
Florence is considered the birthplace of the Renaissance and is home to Michelangelo's famous statue of David.
Seoul is home to five grand palaces, including the famous Gyeongbokgung Palace, which was built in 1395.
Moscow's Red Square is not named for the color red or its association with communism, but from the word 'krasnaya,' meaning 'beautiful' in old Russian.
Krakow’s Main Square is the largest medieval town square in Europe, covering about 40,000 square meters.
Zanzibar is known as the 'Spice Island' due to its vast production of cloves, cinnamon, and nutmeg.
Salzburg is the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and the setting for the famous movie 'The Sound of Music.'
Budapest is actually made up of three cities: Buda, Obuda, and Pest, which were united in 1873.
Hong Kong has more skyscrapers than any other city in the world, with over 8,000 buildings standing taller than 14 stories.
Brisbane is known as the 'River City,' with the Brisbane River winding its way through the heart of the city.
Auckland is home to the Sky Tower, the tallest freestanding structure in the Southern Hemisphere, standing at 328 meters.
Casablanca is home to the Hassan II Mosque, which has the tallest minaret in the world at 210 meters.
Helsinki has been ranked one of the most livable cities in the world and is known for its design and architecture.
Tallinn’s Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, famous for its medieval architecture and cobblestone streets.
Lima was the most important city in Spanish South America during colonial times and is home to the oldest university in the Americas, founded in 1551.
Oslo is one of the world's greenest cities, with vast forest areas within the city limits and 343 lakes.
Dubrovnik's Old Town is completely encircled by well-preserved medieval walls, and is known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic.'
Copenhagen is known for its bike culture, with over 50% of its residents commuting to work or school by bicycle.
